header.relationships: Close family, partners, very close friends
header.topics: Food, childhood toys, family, languages/dialect, work.

sorry to hark back to something that we were talking about earlier but I meant to say erm and then I forgot cos I think I was doing something else but you know how we were talking about how language has changed now?
erm he's recently got a new girlfriend who's from Lithuania
and she's quite young erm well I say she's quite young think she's twenty-one twenty-two so she's
she's a child compared to us

things that are a bit out of her scope but you don't realise that
until you have that person within your midst
just had the same upbringing as you how remote it can be
or if you're learning another language
so I don't know if either of you did any school exchanges er in if you were doing languages at school?
no I didn't do it then
I went to Germany twice so you you s have a pen friend
they come and stay with you and your family
and you go and stay with them in
in their family and it makes you realise that actually what you're taught in school you're er you're ac you're taught very formal textbook languages
but when you get with a family wwith a group of children young adults your age it er see even the way books are written now
compared to b how books were written
they were a lot more formal a lot more
you know structured whereas now it's all sort of chat and conversations
and I've I almost it was like learning German all over again when I was on these exchanges
and you would come back and you'd start using some of the conversation in class and the teacher would say no that's not right
and ththe German teachers I had all through secondary school were either German or they had German parents
so they were brought up with the language but still the way they were teaching it was very very formal
and they wouldn't accept when you say to them well when I stayed with a family
well that's what they say mm
yeah and they didn't say this very formal structured sentence they'd just abbreviate it
and iit it's almost like well you're you're not allowed to say it like that because that won't help you pass your exam
yeah but you know for to put it into practice to actually make use of it
to be able to use it as a language later on
you need to be able to talk the way they talk

a completely different language aren't they?
oh just when I hear like tenses like used really incorrectly and stuff it just
